FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1887.
THE LIBERAL PARTY AND THE NORTHWEST.
It is said of Sandfield Macdonald, that on receiving an invitation to visit the Northwest he answered by replying to Mr. Blake, "I have nothing to do with Strathcona; what has Strathcona to do with me?" So now, that the Liberal party has been invited to visit the Northwest, are we justified in asking, "What has the Liberal party done for the Northwest?" Why should we invite Mr. Blake in? Why should we invite Sir John Macdonald? What claims has Mr. Blake upon us? Why should Mr. Blake keep faith with the British Colonists? Mr. Blake, whose "sole policy" would not have been completed during this century, who made the Northwest a "sterile waste," and endeavored to shirk that nobody could vote for the country by inviting Macdonald and Macdonald, and Blake, for proof of which refer those who may question it to the pages of the Hansard of October 15th and 16th, especially page 1634. For two days thereafter, Mr. Blake endeavored to prove that the Northwest was only fit for Indians to live in. It is true, Mr. Blake has been endeavoring to change a charge, but only since he made a trip to the Rockies over a railway built by the Liberals, and through Liberal party, and through a country they had characterized as a "sterile waste." Mr. Blake has changed his mind with regard to this country, but it is possible that he has not yet seen its merits of settlement. But it should be remembered that the pioneers and late settlers of this country owe Mr. Blake nothing. He has never been here himself, and he has not been west of Ontario, and he has not the confidence of any of that Province. On the other hand, Sir John Macdonald, Sir Charles Tupper, Sir Hector Langevin, Sir Adolph Gordon, Hon. Thomas White, Hon. John Scott, Hon. John Costigan, Hon. Mr. Foster, and other members of the present Government have been here, and visited the British Colonists, and are not only conversant with the wants of the Northwest, but are determined to see that these wants are heard by the North- west despite the opposition of Mr. Blake. No man is more desirous of the good of the Northwest than the Territorial Lord, Sir John Macdonald. No man has brought his natural schemes to greater fruition than he. If Sir Macdonald is not to be said of Saskatchewan, let it not be said of you that you chose another to follow your vote in support of Mr. Blake, that statesman whose life has been devoted to the service of his country, whose name is linked with the greatest national work of any age, and will shine a lasting name our history for all time to come.

Vote for Sir John, the friend of the Northwest.

A WORD TO THE MEN.
We wish to assure you that the time is approaching when we will all have to decide whether we shall be represented in the House of Commons, to give our reasons why we think our votes should go to the Man who should vote for Mr. Macdonald in preference to Mr. Laird. As they well know, Mr. Laird has been a resident of this district nor does he propose to reside here. He simply proposes, if elected, to visit the district occasionally. He has not one cent invested in the country. He has not been in the country for five years. He is a Canadian, but he lives in a part of Canada nearly as far east of Ottawa as we are west of that point. He was Minister of the Interior for three years, but neglected the interests of the Northwest. We believe that the Hon. David Milne, did likewise. As Lieutenant Governor of the Northwest, Mr. Laird has visited this city, but he has not paid. Any gentleman of average ability could fill his position with credit. Mr. Laird, however, thinks that he can. More than this, he comes here on the invitation of the party opposite. Sir John Macdonald, the Premier of Canada. He comes here on the invitation of the party who, as Archibald Taylor says, in connection, mention of death and banishment of the Metis chiefs, and for the failure of the Government to pay them, has been offered before and which we have refused. The men who could do these things are the ones who should be here, and to which Mr. Laird belongs. He comes here on the invitation of the party opposite. Sir John Macdonald, the Premier of Canada. He comes here on the invitation of the party who, as Archibald Taylor says, in connection, mention of death and banishment of the Metis chiefs, and for the failure of the Government to pay them, has been offered before and which we have refused. The men who could do these things are the ones who should be here, and to which Mr. Laird belongs.

M. N. W. in connection with this point are many. By coming here the Company will not only secure the business of the district, but will be able to open up the trails of Battleford and Edmonton during the summer season by placing their goods there. They will also be able to procure Edmonton coal at a much cheaper rate than the present rate. The coal is of good quality, if not better, quality. In fact the advantages to be gained by the Company are making themselves felt in every quarter, and so great that we think the railway cannot be built too rapidly.

Vote for Mr. Macdonald and a real friend of the Northwest.

T. J. AGNEW'S.

ADDRESS

To the Electors of Saskatchewan.

Gentlemen:

At the request of a number of residents in the District of Saskatchewan, I beg to offer myself as a candidate for your suffrages at the coming election as a member of the Federal Parliament.

Should I be returned as your representative I shall use every endeavor to secure the local interests of the District, and shall urge on the Government the necessity of pushing the Railway connection from Prince Albert, Bathurst, and Saskatoon.

The building of a bridge across the Saskatchewan River.

The granting of assistance to the railway to Hudson Bay.

The more liberal issue of scrip to all children of Halfbreed heads of families born in the Territories between 1870 and 1885.

The recommendation of the permit system to the liquor question.

The speedy payment on a liberal scale of all just claims against the Government.

The granting of seed grain free of charge to the poor.

The purchasing of supplies for public purposes in the district in which they are consumed.

The formation of a Legislative Assembly for the Territories in which Saskatchewan shall have full and proper representation.

A man whose main interests are closely identified with the future of Saskatchewan, I appeal to every elector in the district for support during the contest.

I am, gentlemen,

Your obedient servant,

D. H. Macdonald.

Aux Electeurs du District de Saskatchewan.

Messieurs :

À la demande d'un nombre d'habitants du District de Saskatchewan, j'ai bien l'honneur de m'offrir à vous comme candidat pour votre suffrage dans l'élection prochaine d'un membre pour le Parlement Fédéral.

Dans ce cas où je serais élu, je recommande vivement les mesures suivantes :

La construction d'un pont sur le fleuve Saskatchewan.

La distribution de subventions pour le chemin de fer vers le golfe de Hudson.

La plus large distribution de billets de scolarité aux enfants des familles de tête de famille nées entre 1870 et 1885 dans les Territoires.

La recommandation du système de permis pour la question de l'alcool.

Le paiement rapide et généreux des dettes de l'État.

La distribution gratuite des graines de semence aux habitants du territoire.

La formation d'une Assemblée législative pour les Territoires dans lesquels Saskatchewan sera pleinement représentée.

Un homme dont les intérêts sont étroitement liés à l'avenir de Saskatchewan, je me tourne vers chaque électeur du district pour son soutien pendant la campagne.

Je suis, messieurs,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

D. H. Macdonald.
ELECTION NOTES.

A meeting of Mr. Macdonald’s Central Committee will take place tomorrow night at Sir John Macdonald’s residence. The standard joke of the campaign is to get two groups together and ask them to define their Liberal principles. It rarely leads to a split in the party.

Vote for a member of Saskatchewan, and F. E. Land Seabrook.

The Detroit Evening News says: “The article in the Standard of Toronto, to which Sir John Macdonald ought to be attached, has become inflammatory, and will endanger his popularity. He has been accused of seeking to force down the pay of workingmen, and his concessions have been interpreted as leading to a decline in public services. Mr. and Mrs. Peter Burrows, therefore, urge Macdonald not to yield further concessions to the Labour policy.”

MME POLE MOFFAT ADDRESSES THE CROWD.

Mrs. Pole Moffat addressed the crowd at the railway station yesterday afternoon, and praised Mr. Lafontaine’s speech. She said: “We are all united against Mr. Lafontaine’s attacks on domestic duties.” Mrs. Moffat also spoke in favour of the Liberal party, and ended her address by saying: “Mr. Lafontaine’s remarks were offensive to women, and we shall unite to oppose him.”
